								I'll start this by saying that I really do like the game and its concept. The mechanics, while frustrating at times, feel like they have a certain fun in their novelty, and I do enjoy all of the various adjusting and full control that they've tried to implemment in this game. Based on these factors alone, I would be tempted to give this game a positive review; all that being said, I do not give this game a strong recommendation however much I would like to. The positive attributes that D.U.S.T. holds are currently overshadowed by the lack of player-base, the oversimplistic map design, and the general disorganization of layout. It becomes very apparent that the game lacks a large enough playerbase to produce exciting matches when the only server containing more than 0-1 players is comprised of 90% bots. This point alone would not generally turn me off to the game; I play many games regularly such as Insurgency, Star Wars Batllefront II, CS:GO, etc. which benefit greatly from the inclusion of bots and remain entertaining when playing matches even entirely comprised of NPCs/AI. But the nature of the bots in D.U.S.T. are simply frustrating. After spending so much time setting myself up (filling my canteen, adjusting sights, slowly travelling across the colossal empty plains, etc.), it is severely enraging to find that I am immediately acquired and killed by a bot from 75+ meters away with god-like accuracy. I understand that this game is intended for a hardcore, simulation audience, but when the average player, or even perhaps an operator in the real world, takes much more effort in the way of aim and could expend an entire magazine before being able accurately hit their target at medium-long ranges, it is severely enraging to find myself targetted and dropped by a bot after immediate, inhuman adjustmentsand  only 2-3 rounds sent my way. This simple gripe would be forgivable in its own right, perhaps it would even be an endearing quality. D.U.S.T. is, after all, intended to be a very hardcore, unforgiving simulation game, however a problem arises when this effect is combined with my other two component gripes with this game: scope of map design and organization of its layout.The design of the map in this game is ambitious, something which I generally admire about this project as a whole. Its 4km x 4km in size, a titantic playing area for a first person shooter, especially one without an established publisher's support. This is something I would generally have considered a positive trait, and something which actually drew me in primarily; but it is also fundamentally flawed considering the overall developmental state the game is currently in, a point which I will further explain after establishing my dependent complaint in the map's organization. The general layout of this map, disregarding its size, is quite good actually. There is a central city, positioned in a "bowl" of surrounding hills; American and Russian "control points" are tangent to the North and South of the city respectively and factional deployment areas are located within 50-100m of these points. The central city contains a sizable quantity of various buildings and cover elements which the player is allowed to interact with, enter and utilize in avoiding enemy fire. The control points are each composed of a tall building, a surrounding wall, small cover elements, and a water dispensary to fill canteens. The spawns are comprised of a small amount of cleverly placed sandboxes and trucks which allow you to take cover and find your bearings before heading into battle. I am quite fond of each of these elements to be clear, and I'd add that the relative location of each is ideal; however, an unwelcome situation is created when these elements are placed into such a substantially sized map. The size calls for each of these elements to be placed (I'll add that I am not quite sure of the exact distances as I'm unaware to if they've been recorded) seemingly 100s of meters apart from one another. What I would initially consider an adequate, possibly even accomplished, map design becomes exhausting and irritating considering the fundamental mechanics of this game (which I've noted before are a postitive attribute and even a drawing factor to me personally.) You are first deployed in the spawn with an empty canteen and an unadjusted, unloaded rifle. To fill the canteen, you must walk to the water dispensary in the control point area, open your canteen [MMB], turn on the tap [`], close your canteen when its full [LMB], and turn the tap back off [`]; to bring your rifle to a usable state, you need to bring your rifle up [RMB], pull the charging handle [RShift], aim down sights [RMB], adjust your head position relative to your sights [LMB+Mouse movement], and change firing mode to semi or full [Up arrow, Right arrow]. These mechanics are essential to your survival and your abilty to take down hostile targets. They are also refreshing, immersive, involved, and above all else, entertaining. But when these mechanics must be repeated upon each deployment (respawn), they become time-consuming, especially considering the 100m or so journey to the water dispensary, and then the several hundred more meters you must trek to make it into the main town. This repetition is exhausting and takes much too much time away from possible engagements and firefights.In conclusion, I cannot recommend this game, at this point, to anyone. The game simply does not give enough reward to your efforts when adjusting your gear and making it into battle comprise the majority of time spent playing. I would, however, like to specify that most of these points are intrinsic to the stage of development. This game has significant potential and I would love to see where its development leads. I can even forgive all the negative aspects, there is true thought and merit put into each one, and they only become negative due to the lack of synergy between them. I've taken this time to write such a lengthy and detailed review because I believe that it would be simple (although perhaps not without spending a deal of time) to assimilate these seperate parts into a smoother, better-operating machine. The main problem, the gist of my issue with this game lies in its current map size. A playable 4km x 4km landscape is a great goal to set for completion in the later stages of development, but at this point, with the current "density" so to speak of the map elements, it is simply to large. My main advice to the development team would be to remove all the elements of the map, save the foundation landscape into a seperate file for optimization at a later date, and place the elements into a more compact landscape, perhaps with more cover in the plains of sand between each distinct map location. Once the elements are more reasonably spaced and condensed, I have a feeling that this game will become much more playable, with the various small grievances becoming insignificant. An optional change which may be of use would be to save the player's rifle adjustments between lives. Although this specific change I'll admit may be detrimental to the games spirit, it could reduce time taken between death and reaching your squadmates, and could create a more inviting atmosphere for groups of players looking for a tactical, squad-reliant shooter. The best option regarding this specific idea may be to allow the player to decide whether they'd like their adjustments saved in the settings.I really do hope that you see this, development team, because I deeply enjoy the fundamentals of this game, and I've only taken the effort to write such a wordy, exploratory review because I love this concept and I'd like to see where you can take it. My lack of recommendation is tied to the current state of the game, and I look forward to when I will be able to recommend this game to every single one of my friends and acquaintances in the near future.

D.U.S.T: Unforgiving RealismUnless you insert the full title of the game into Google your not going to get much information, although i have not seen mutch information on this game other than the odd forum post on other game pages saying Arma meets Receiver etc (never played Receiver) the complexity of the game is not for the typical "Run and Gun" gamer.This game requires some learning to play, there is no instructions on what you have to do, no back story, and there appears to only be one objective at this time - Capture the FOBs.As i previously mentioned the game is not for your typical run and gun gamer, the reason for this is because you have to operate your firearm and equipment similar to how you would in the real world, you have diferent button combinations to arm your rifle, you have to adjust your sights and you have to ensure you get yourself some water from the closest FOB. if you dont.... well you wont last too long as the map currently in the gamee is HUGE. with no vehicles (for now) it can take some time to get from spawn to the various FOBs.if you are considering getting the game, take this into consideration.How to arm and shoot your gun 101... (spoiler)• press RIGHT SHIFT to pull your charging handle back - to load a round into the chamber• press the UP or RIGHT arrow on your keyboard - to select single or full auto• press and hold both LEFT & RIGHT mouse buttons and move your mouse - to line your sights up• press in the MIDDLE MOUSE wheel - to put your finger on the trigger• while still holding the middle mousse wheel in SCROLL DOWN - to pull the triggerThat my friends is just how you shoot your gun.Conclusion & final ThaughtsThere is a lot of pottential in this game but the target audience is very narrow, mainly for those who enjoy milsim games and want to have that feel of being a hardcore operator, although the gameplay is limited at this time it is a great game to say it is currently being made by a single guy who has so far definatly put out, there is a road map within the game that shoows what features are due to  be implimented and you can see the ccurrent progress of the development which is a real nice touch.all in all i have to give this game, and the developer a 7/10

Pros:Mechanic wise the game feels good, but rough.Sound effects are well made.Lots of in-depth weapon customization planned.Friendly community.Graphics are fine and so is the performance.Cons:Game is very bare and there isn't much content.Sound distance is messed up in 0.2.0.0 and it's not very enjoyable.Steep learning curve if you have no idea of what you're doing.Bugs, bugs everywhere!(Early-Access*cough*)No vehicles(yet), alot of running ahead of you.Conclusion:As of the early-access release patch I wouldn't recommend anyone to buy it if they're looking for a GAME to play, however you like the concept of the game and want to take part in TESTING and help finding bugs then this is definitely for you, plus you may also have something to say when it comes to new mechanics and items.Great game if you enjoy games like Arma, Squad & DayZ, but want the realism turned up a tad more.While the game isn't clunky when you already know all the keybinds and trust me, there's alot of them that you have to remember, it certainly is trial and error for the first few hours,However, this is an early-access title afterall and you have to consider that if you're considering of buying it. Right now, if you just press random buttons you'll eventually end up being stuck on whatever weapon/item you're currently carrying and have to rejoin the server to fix it.Almost every item in the game as of 0.2.0.0 can potentially bug your animation and lock it completely.Why am I recommending the game when it is clearly broken?I have personally been looking for a title like this for a very long time and this is just a bare core-concept of what the game is going to be like when Terapoly starts to update it.Some people may like all the complicated things that you have to do, some may not. Once you get the hang of it, it's not really that complicated.Most of the keybinds are placed in such a way that it makes sense when you know what you're doing, therefor making the learning curve very steep if you have zero knowledge of how a gun work but once you know those things it just makes sense in some way.While I'm only 20'ish hours into the game I've already experience multiple adrenaline rushes.That one second when you're about to engage in a firefight with someone and everything is in slow-motion, you have to know how and what to do with your gun and I guess that is what makes it so satisfying.YOU ACTUALLY HAVE TO THINK WHILE PLAYING.In the current state the game isn't about just killing and shooting everyone you see; It's EARLY-ACCES after all.Yes, you can join a server, figure out how to shoot and have fun for a couple of hours, but that's about it, so if you plan on buying it to PLAY it and not TEST it then I'd advise you to look elsewhere until Terapoly pushes out some updates to make the game more stable, because if you try to play it just to play it, you'll  end up quitting before you learn how to shoot your gun because of all the frustrating bugs.As everyone else said please take a tour around Terapoly's forums to better ready yourself before you enter the battlefield of D.U.S.T.Review posted on early-access release version 0.2.0.0 - I'll update it as we get updates for the game.

								It's a good concept, and it functions just as advertised, but as of right now, it's barely a game. First off, the game dropped me in with no instruction but a mostly incomplete controls sheet. The "field manuals" were nowhere to be found on the store page or the game's website. By the time I was able to operate my gun and start making my way around the map, I started getting a weird visual distortion effect. I figured out that I was dying of thirst and needed to get my canteen out. When I finally found the number (7) to equip it, it took me another 2 minutes to actually open it and take a drink. It follows the same weird and unintuitive scroll-wheel system that the guns use to open it, take a drink, and close it. I was only able to take 1 drink, which halfed the distortion, and then it appeared that my canteen was empty. 5 minutes later I was dead.I'm sure that all of these seemingly broken features and empty canteens actually work, and have some sort of obscure keybind or scrollwheel manipulation technique that gets them to, but it seems like every little function in this game warrants it's own youtube tutorial. I would give this game a thumbs up if it had any sort of training system or even a set of tips to help a normal person play the game, but at this stage, that doesn't exist. Give this one a few development stages before you go after it, unless you are content with confusing controls and bad keybinding systems.

Early Access Review
								DISCLAIMER: This game IS Early Access, as in VERY early access. There ARE many bugs, weird issues, and wonky UI to work around. There ARE often teamkillers in spawn and the first outpost, and there are not that many people playing at the moment.That out of the way, this game looks really promising. For several reasons:1. The concept is REALLY cool! And what's here right now matches the concept pretty well. You need to load a round into the chamber (left shift), take the safty off (down arrow), and then pull the trigger (in a much more interesting way than normal: press and scroll back on the middle mouse button). And that's just the gun. You also need to use a water bottle to stay hydrated in the desert, move your head to be in line with the sights, and you will most likely die on the second (if not the first) shot that hits you.2. The community (aside from the teamkillers) is pretty helpful. Everyone's new to the game, but people who understand the controls will often respond to questions posed in the chat on what to do to get playing. And there's a lot of questions asked in chat...3. (side note) The teamkillers (in my experience) generally just hang around the team spawn, and sometimes the first outpost. All I've had to do to generally avoid them is to sprint away as soon as I spawn, fill up my canteen, and head for one of the three middle bases to start capping the flags.4. The map is HUGE! I've still never made it to the enemy spawn, because it's at least a 5-10 minute sprint away. That walled tower everyone sees when they spawn is just the first outpost. If you go over the hill behind it, you'll see a huge valley with three unique bases, each of which has a flag to cap. (And yes, the flags work, they just take a REALLY long time to come down).5. The devs have been decently transparent about what's been happening, and have stated they plan to release some patches very soon (like within the week, as of 10/21/15)So, conclusion? If you're willing to take the effort to learn how to work with your equipment, and work around the bugs in a very early access game, then go ahead! Pick up a copy and try it! The devs have only been working on this for about 6 months, as a 2 person team, so the state the game is in right now is actually pretty impressive.If you aren't willing to deal with issues that an Early Access game is bound to have (not going to go on a rant...), don't buy it. Yet. Definitly look into buying it at some point. But don't give it a bad review quite yet, when you've already been warned by this and other reviews.Two last notes: If you don't like the 120 second respawn timer? Reloging doesn't take that long (about 30-50 seconds, maybe), and you may have to relog anyway on account of glitches.If you want a game to try that incorporates similar realistic physics and gun handling, try the (albeit singleplayer) game "Reciever".

								After playing it for a short while I am ready to give my impressions.I will present them in a + - list. I will try to avoid crritisizing things that are obviously WIPFirst off, most negative reviews seem to be dorf syndrome - people reacting negatively to the difficulty/learning curve rather than actual problems.+atmosphere is there - two factions fighting in a barren desert for water. There is a lot of empty space between each area and it's quite... comfy-some clunky controls that are there just for sake of inconveniencing - EG having to unscrew and rescrew cap for the canteen, open/close the lid of a compass. The animations are a bit too slow. While the slow speed of using equipment can be a great gameplay mechanic, I don't think it is a good idea to make it frustrating and annoying to use. There's nothing you can do with a closed compass or a closed canteen. Having an extra closed states serves no function other than a filler. It's like having a scene in a movie which does not evolve the characters or drive the plot forward - just useless filler you're better off cutting.-/+Lack of generic interaction key - operating taps on water drums requires you to use two keys to close and open it. There's no reason it could not be done with one key. Unless developers are planning to use two interaction keys as part of gameplay+never before seen control over your firearm - sure it's a bit clunky(mostly since we can't rebind controls yet) but once you get used to it its miles ahead of Receiver. +lack of UI - this makes game both more immersive and interesting since you have to look at the object to know it's state. EG wether a magazine is full or empty.  I do hope however, that we will see an "inventory" where you can see how many items you have left and repack magazines-loadout screen is a bit basic - could use the ability to configure what goes into each item slot(pouch)+vast scale of map - despite being large (Project Reality scale) it isn't painful to traverse on foot. Moving to an objective only takes a few minutes and you can use that time to keep an eye on it.+implementation of water - I do hope this stays at near central importance as of gameplay, since the idea of two ragged armies fighting over basic resources and for their survival sounds a lot more appealing than  generic milsim with two well supplied armies+large servers and no matchmaking +weapon customisation - you can select optics, barrels, foregrips, muzzle devices, stocks and triggers+bold and avant garde approach to weapon controls and firing mechanics - trying to change something that's been standard to the genre since it's birth is admirable. And it works!Overall it's pretty bared bones now, buggy, not juicy and poorly animated. It still is something new and different.Hope developers don't ditch this game 20% into the development like most others.

								Not recommended IF: You are expecting a completed game. Recommended IF: You like the idea of this game, don't mind it being (quite) rough around the edges, and want to support the development of this game. I am glad I bought it, as I would like to see it developed further. Overall, the controls are clunky- but if you read the guides it's not very difficult. The game is easier for me to play with a steam controller than it is with KB+M.Pros: - More depth to reloading and operating your weapons. Reloading is not just a click and wait. Did you save a round in the chamber?- Graphics options are not bad.- Customizing your weapon is cool (though somewhat limited)- Large Map- Fun multiplayer when there are people to play with- Recoil Effects and shooting is a blast.- Going to jail for Team Killing really makes you want to identify your targets correctly and helps deal with trolling.Cons: - Map is empty and lacks diversity- Player movement is very 0 / 1 feeling... clunky.- Animations need work- In-Game sounds need work- Basic tasks are not straight-forward enough. ( ~ + 7 + MMB + hold R + left click + ~ to fill water bottle) In game tutorial would help.- Bullet ballistics do not seem ... very complex. It hits the reticle pretty much without any adjustment.- the AI seems VERY dumb. They just stand there, or just stand there and shoot.- Only two weapons, one for each side.What I would like to see is more fluid movement, a smaller, more dense map with less bots (or none)... basically CQB designed for ~8-32 players. Also, make the gun float around the screen to require the use of iron sights / scopes... otherwise however you adjust your head --> sights... it always will shoot at the center of the screen.  TLDR: I look forward to seeing how this game develops. Buy if you want to support the development. In it's current state, it's not worth what you pay for it, but it has a lot of potential... and is worth it if the developer puts some more love into it! I am happy with the purchase.

								If I could give this title a "maybe" I would.  I'm going to upvote it for now, because I think it's really unfair to review it at this point, and I think as gamers we tend not to revisit products we saw that had mixed and negative ratings. Be forewarned:  I would only pick this title up if you want to support the dev's vision of the game and you want to be an active tester. Slower even then ARMA.  If you watch live combat footage then you start to see similarities between it and this game.  There is a significantly slower pace to combat, and initially it will shock casual shooter players, because the mechanics require you to do more than left click to shoot and tap R to reload.  It's slightly awkward at first, but once you get used to the keypresses needed to operate your weapon or supporting gear, it isn't too bad.  Right now there isn't a whole lot to shoot but bots, and not a whole lot to tinker with on the gun bench.  I'm sure that will all come in time.  How much time?  Considering it's a two man dev team, and their roadmap is somewhat ambitious, perhaps two years to release?
